segment.source: Windows Setup: Installing using the MBR or GPT partition style
segment.target: Windows Setup: Installing using the MBR or GPT partition style

segment.source: Windows Setup: Installing using the MBR or GPT partition style
segment.target: Windows Setup: Installing using the MBR or GPT partition style

segment.source: Windows Setup: Installing using the MBR or GPT partition style
segment.target: Windows Setup: Installing using the MBR or GPT partition style

segment.source: When installing Windows on UEFI-based PCs using Windows Setup, your hard drive partition style must be set up to support either UEFI mode or legacy BIOS-compatibility mode.
segment.target: When installing Windows on UEFI-based PCs using Windows Setup, your hard drive partition style must be set up to support either UEFI mode or legacy BIOS-compatibility mode.

segment.source: For example, if you receive the error message: “Windows cannot be installed to this disk.
segment.target: For example, if you receive the error message: “Windows cannot be installed to this disk.

segment.source: The selected disk is not of the GPT partition style”, it’s because your PC is booted in UEFI mode, but your hard drive is not configured for UEFI mode.
segment.target: The selected disk is not of the GPT partition style”, it’s because your PC is booted in UEFI mode, but your hard drive is not configured for UEFI mode.

segment.source: You’ve got a few options:
segment.target: You’ve got a few options:

segment.source: Reboot the PC in legacy BIOS-compatibility mode.
segment.target: Reboot the PC in legacy BIOS-compatibility mode.

segment.source: This option lets you keep the existing partition style.
segment.target: This option lets you keep the existing partition style.

segment.source: For more info, see Boot to UEFI Mode or Legacy BIOS mode.
segment.target: For more info, see Boot to UEFI Mode or Legacy BIOS mode.

segment.source: Reformat the drive for UEFI by using the GPT partition style.
segment.target: Reformat the drive for UEFI by using the GPT partition style.

segment.source: This option lets you use the PC’s UEFI firmware features.
segment.target: This option lets you use the PC’s UEFI firmware features.

segment.source: You can do this yourself by reformatting the drive using the instructions below, or if you need to preserve the data, use a third-party utility to convert the drive to GPT format.
segment.target: You can do this yourself by reformatting the drive using the instructions below, or if you need to preserve the data, use a third-party utility to convert the drive to GPT format.

segment.source: Why should I convert my drive?
segment.target: Why should I convert my drive?

segment.source: Many PCs now include the ability to use the UEFI version of BIOS, which can speed up boot and shutdown times and can provide additional security advantages.
segment.target: Many PCs now include the ability to use the UEFI version of BIOS, which can speed up boot and shutdown times and can provide additional security advantages.

segment.source: To boot your PC in UEFI mode, you'll need to use a drive formatted using the GPT drive format.
segment.target: To boot your PC in UEFI mode, you'll need to use a drive formatted using the GPT drive format.

segment.source: Many PCs are ready to use UEFI, but include a compatibility support module (CSM) that is set up to use the legacy version of BIOS.
segment.target: Many PCs are ready to use UEFI, but include a compatibility support module (CSM) that is set up to use the legacy version of BIOS.

segment.source: This version of BIOS was developed in the 1970s and provides compatibility to a variety of older equipment and network configurations, and requires a drive that uses the MBR drive format.
segment.target: This version of BIOS was developed in the 1970s and provides compatibility to a variety of older equipment and network configurations, and requires a drive that uses the MBR drive format.

segment.source: However, the basic MBR drive format does not support drives over 4TB.
segment.target: However, the basic MBR drive format does not support drives over 4TB.

segment.source: It's also difficult to set up more than four partitions.
segment.target: It's also difficult to set up more than four partitions.

segment.source: The GPT drive format lets you set up drives that are larger than 4 terabytes (TB), and lets you easily set up as many partitions as you need.
segment.target: The GPT drive format lets you set up drives that are larger than 4 terabytes (TB), and lets you easily set up as many partitions as you need.

segment.source: Reformatting the drive using a different partition style
segment.target: Reformatting the drive using a different partition style

segment.source: To wipe and convert the drive by using Windows Setup
segment.target: To wipe and convert the drive by using Windows Setup

segment.source: Turn off the PC, and put in the Windows installation DVD or USB key.
segment.target: Turn off the PC, and put in the Windows installation DVD or USB key.

segment.source: Boot the PC to the DVD or USB key in UEFI mode.
segment.target: Boot the PC to the DVD or USB key in UEFI mode.

segment.source: For more info, see Boot to UEFI Mode or Legacy BIOS mode.
segment.target: For more info, see Boot to UEFI Mode or Legacy BIOS mode.

segment.source: When choosing an installation type, select Custom.
segment.target: When choosing an installation type, select Custom.

segment.source: On the Where do you want to install Windows? screen, select each of the partitions on the drive, and select Delete.
segment.target: On the Where do you want to install Windows? screen, select each of the partitions on the drive, and select Delete.

segment.source: The drive will show a single area of unallocated space.
segment.target: The drive will show a single area of unallocated space.

segment.source: Select the unallocated space and click Next.
segment.target: Select the unallocated space and click Next.

segment.source: Windows detects that the PC was booted into UEFI mode, and reformats the drive using the GPT drive format, and begins the installation.
segment.target: Windows detects that the PC was booted into UEFI mode, and reformats the drive using the GPT drive format, and begins the installation.

segment.source: To manually wipe a drive and convert it to GPT:
segment.target: To manually wipe a drive and convert it to GPT:

segment.source: Turn off the PC, and put in the Windows installation DVD or USB key.
segment.target: Turn off the PC, and put in the Windows installation DVD or USB key.

segment.source: Boot the PC to the DVD or USB key in UEFI mode.
segment.target: Boot the PC to the DVD or USB key in UEFI mode.

segment.source: For more info, see Boot to UEFI Mode or Legacy BIOS mode.
segment.target: For more info, see Boot to UEFI Mode or Legacy BIOS mode.

segment.source: From inside Windows Setup, press Shift+F10 to open a command prompt window.
segment.target: From inside Windows Setup, press Shift+F10 to open a command prompt window.

segment.source: Open the diskpart tool:
segment.target: Open the diskpart tool:

segment.source: Identify the drive to reformat:
segment.target: Identify the drive to reformat:

segment.source: Select the drive, and reformat it:
segment.target: Select the drive, and reformat it:

segment.source: Close the command prompt window.
segment.target: Close the command prompt window.

segment.source: Continue the Windows Setup installation.
segment.target: Continue the Windows Setup installation.

segment.source: When choosing an installation type, select Custom.
segment.target: When choosing an installation type, select Custom.

segment.source: The drive will appear as a single area of unallocated space.
segment.target: The drive will appear as a single area of unallocated space.

segment.source: Select the unallocated space and click Next.
segment.target: Select the unallocated space and click Next.

segment.source: Windows begins the installation.
segment.target: Windows begins the installation.

segment.source: Make sure Windows Setup boots to the correct firmware mode
segment.target: Make sure Windows Setup boots to the correct firmware mode

segment.source: To automate this process, you'll need to run Windows Setup through Windows PE, and use a script to detect which mode you’re in before installing Windows.
segment.target: To automate this process, you'll need to run Windows Setup through Windows PE, and use a script to detect which mode you’re in before installing Windows.

segment.source: For more info, see WinPE: Boot in UEFI or legacy BIOS mode.
segment.target: For more info, see WinPE: Boot in UEFI or legacy BIOS mode.
